title-group.article-title: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
On the boundary of the jumping spider genus
Rhyphelia Simon, 1902
( Araneae : Salticidae : Euophryini), with description of ten new species
WELINGTON B. NOBRE 1 & GUSTAVO R.S. RUIZ 2*

1
Programa de Pós-Graduação em Zoologia, Universidade Federal do Pará / Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi, Brazil
� welingtonbnobre99@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0009-0006-3145-0989

2
Instituto de Ciências Biológicas, Universidade Federal do Pará, Rua Augusto Corrêa, 01, CEP 66075-110, Belém, PA , Brazil
� gustavoruiz86@hotmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7326-7000
* Corresponding author

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
In this paper we synonymize
Soesilarishius Makhan, 2007
with
Rhyphelia Simon, 1902
. We give new illustrations of the male holotype of the type species
Rhyphelia variegata Simon, 1902
for comparisons, and describe the closely related
Rhyphelia brevistylus
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from the state of Bahia, Brazil . Additionally, we describe nine other new species from different Brazilian regions:
Rhyphelia barbado
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Bahia ,
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from Minas Gerais ,
Rhyphelia cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Mato Grosso ,
Rhyphelia gallina
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Acre ,
Rhyphelia novalima
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) and
Rhyphelia okay
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from Minas Gerais ,
Rhyphelia otti
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from Rio Grande do Sul ,
Rhyphelia planaria
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from São Paulo , and
Rhyphelia tocantinensis
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Tocantins .

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: Brazil
, Salticinae ,
Soesilarishius
,
new synonym , new combination
, taxonomy

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Euophryini is still mainly defined by the morphology of the male palp, with a spiraled embolus restricted to the most distal portion of the bulb, with the plane of the spiral almost parallel to the longitudinal axis of the palp and with a retrolateral loop of the spermophore (RSDL) towards the central area of the tegulum (
: fig. 4A). Although this pattern of male palp is present in almost all genera of the tribe, others have different embolus and may have lost the spermophore loop (
: fig. 4G). Females of Euophryini usually have a pair of large areas covered with a thin cuticle on the epigyne, called the “windows”, through which it is possible to visualize the spermathecae located inside the body (
: figs 4B, 4J). However, the windows may also be absent in some groups (see
: figs 4D, 4H), including in many related Neotropical lineages (
,
), such as
Soesilarishius
,
Rhyphelia
,
Marma Simon, 1902
(see
: figs 6C, 7G, 7H),
Amphidraus Simon, 1900
(see
: figs 4C, 5F) and
Neonella Gertsch, 1936
(see
: figs 4F, 4G). Most of these absences/reductions, however, may be homoplasies, since the epigynal windows are present in other related genera in the same clade, such as
Coryphasia Simon, 1902
and
Ilargus Simon, 1901
(
).

The genus
Soesilarishius
was proposed by
with only the type species
S. amrishi Makhan, 2007
described from a male specimen collected in Suriname .
gathered a group of seven species as belonging in the genus and transferred
Euophrys aurifrons Taczanowski, 1878
to
Soesilarishius
. Since then, other species have been described in the genus (
;
;
).
also redescribed the male and described the previously unknown female of the type species. Hitherto, the genus is composed of 23 species, 17 of which have been described with both male and female, and six only with male (
). Spiders of
Soesilarishius
are found in different biomes of South America, usually on the ground in vegetation-covered areas (
), where a high layer of litter is accumulated.Although corroborated with molecular data as a true Euophryini (
,
), this genus does not have the typical spiraled embolus of the tribe. Instead, species of
Soesilarishius
exhibit great diversity in the morphology of the male palps and epigynes (e.g.
,
).

Rhyphelia
, on the other hand, is a poorly known monotypic genus. The type species
R. variegata Simon, 1902
(only the male is known) was redescribed by
, and the genus was considered probably closely related to
Soesilarishius
due to the similar morphology of the male palp (
).

Considering the morphological diversity present in the lineage, we herein synonymize
Rhyphelia
and
Soesilarishius
based on their similar body form and genitalic structures. In addition, ten new species are described, which furtherering the morphological diversity present in the lineage, increase the species diversity of this group.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: The material belongs to the Museu de Ciências Naturais, Fundação Zoobotânica do Rio Grande do Sul (MCN/ FZBRS; curator: R. Ott); Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi (MPEG; curator: A. Bonaldo); Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG; curator: A. Santos); and the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris (MNHN; curator: C. Rollard).
Geographic coordinates are expressed in decimal degrees and were taken directly from labels.

The order of species descriptions is given to maximize comparisons between similar species across the manuscript, as follows: the type species of
Rhyphelia
, followed by the striking similar
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
, followed by the
R. barbado
sp. nov.
/
R. otti
sp. nov.
pair, which should be preferably compared side by side, the unusual
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
, followed by the
R. cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
/
R. tocantinensis
sp. nov.
and the
R. gallina
sp. nov.
/
R. planaria
sp. nov.
pairs, which should be preferably compared side by side, followed by
R. novalima
sp. nov.
and
R. okay
sp. nov.

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
( Type species:
Rhyphelia variegata Simon, 1902
, by original designation); World Spider Catalog 2023 .

( Type species:
Soesilarishius amrishi Makhan, 2007
, by original designation); World Spider Catalog 2023 — NEW SYNONYMY .

Diagnosis. Species included in this genus are small, brownish South American litter or trunk dwelling euophryines with reduced spiraled emboli (for further notes, see Galiano 1963 ; Ruiz 2011 , 2013 ; Zhang & Maddison 2015 ; Ruiz & Sobrinho 2016 ). In that sense,
Rhyphelia
resembles the unrelated
Popcornella
from the Caribbean islands, but
Popcornella
has a short retrolateral tibial apophysis in the male palp (larger in
Rhyphelia
) and shortened copulatory ducts in the epigyne (longer in
Rhyphelia
) (See Zhang & Maddison, 2012b : figs 219–223).

Phylogenetic position. According to Zhang & Maddison (2015) , this group (included as “
Soesilarishius
” in the analyses) was found as part of a Neotropical clade gathering other genera, such as
Amphidraus
,
Marma
,
Tylogonus Simon, 1902
,
Mopiopia Simon, 1902
,
Saphrys Zhang & Maddison, 2015
,
Coryphasia
,
Neonella
,
Ecuadattus Zhang & Maddison, 2012
and
Ilargus
. The similar morphology present in some
Rhyphelia
and in
Popcornella
(body size, coloration, reduced structures in male palp and epigyne) represent, hence, convergences, since these genera are not closely related (see Zhang & Maddison 2015 ).

Note. Males of two species (
R. variegata
and
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
) have projected endites (
) and developed tegular lobe, both absent or reduced in the remaining species of the genus. However, these structures are extremely variable in Euophryini and were considered not enough to predict the independence of both genera, given the diversity of the lineage. Unpublished DNA sequences of an undescribed species from Ecuador closely related to the type species,
R. variegata
, places the Ecuadorian species with the remaining species of the lineage sampled in molecular studies (
R. amrishi
,
R. micacea
and
R. ruizi
; see species authors below) (W. Maddison, pers. comm). Despite several species already being described, analyses of Brazilian collections show that this lineage is one of the largest ground-dwelling spider groups in South America in terms of species number, with many more species awaiting formal description. Given the similarities, the large number of genera in the tribe, the close relationship between type species demonstrated with DNA sequences and, most importantly, to ensure taxonomic stability, we decided to synonymize the two genera herein.

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Diagnosis. The male of
R. variegata
is similar to that of
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
by the longer carapace (about 1.5x longer than wide,
,
; shorter, 1.3–1.4x longer than wide in the remaining species), by the developed tegular lobe (
,
) and by the spurs on the border of the endites (
). The male of
R. variegata
differs from that of
R. brevistylus
by the long embolus, which reaches almost the length of the tegulum (
) (about one third the length of tegulum in
R. brevistylus
;
). The female is unknown.

Redescription. See Galiano (1963) . Herein we give new illustrations of the holotype for comparison (
).

Distribution. The original description mentions Caracas ( Venezuela ) as the type locality, but the label states the actual type locality in the state of Rio de Janeiro , Brazil ( Galiano 1963 ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Mata da Tijuquinha , Serra do Barbado , Distrito de Catolés , Abaíra , Bahia , Brazil ( 13.269°S , 41.911°W ),
1.XI.2013
, L.S Carvalho & M.B da Silva leg. (UFMG 14990)
.
Paratypes :
1♂ 1♀ , from Parque Estadual da Serra do Japi , Jundiaí , São Paulo , Brazil ( 23.283°S 46.983°W ),
3.XI.2007
, J. Sobjack leg. (UFMG 6478)
.
Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a compound noun in apposition, is a combination of Latin adjective “brevis” (short) and noun “stylus” (embolus).

Diagnosis. The male of
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
is similar to that of
R. variegata
by the longer carapace (about 1.5x longer than wide,
,
; shorter, 1.3–1.4x longer than wide in the remaining species), by the developed tegular lobe (
,
) and by the spurs on the border of the endites. The male of
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
differs from that of
R. variegata
by the shorter embolus, which reaches about one third the length of tegulum (
) (almost the length of the tegulum in
R. variegata
;
). The female differs from all the other species of the genus by having copulatory openings facing ectally, followed by anterior ducts with large secondary spermathecae (
,
).

Distribution. Known only from the states of Bahia and São Paulo , Brazil (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Mata da Tijuquinha , Serra do Barbado , Distrito de Catolés , Abaíra , Bahia , Brazil ( 13.269°S , 41.911°W ),
1.XI.2013
, L.S. Carvalho & M.B. da Silva leg. (UFMG 14979).
Etymology. Epithet, a noun in apposition, is taken from type locality.

Diagnosis. Among the species of the genus, the male of
R. barbado
sp. nov.
is most similar to that of
R. otti
sp. nov.
, as it has an elongated and flattened embolus, almost parallel to the longitudinal axis, with a fold at the most apical region (compare
). The male of
R. barbado
sp. nov.
can be distinguished by the membranous lamella on the prolateral side of the embolus (
; smooth embolus in
S. otti
sp. nov.
,
).
Female. Unknown.

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Bahia , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from
Centro de Pesquisas
e Conservação da Natureza Pró-Mata , São Francisco de Paula , Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil ,
02.I.2001
, R. Ott leg. (MCN/FZBRS-39661)
.
Paratype :
1♀ , same data as holotype (MCN/FZBRS-39661)
.
Etymology. Epithet is in honour of the Brazilian arachnologist Ricardo Ott, who collected the type specimens.

Diagnosis. Among the species of the genus, the male of
R. otti
sp. nov.
is most similar to that of
R. barbado
sp. nov.
, as it has an elongated and flattened embolus, almost parallel to the longitudinal axis, with a fold at the most apical region (compare
). The male of
R. otti
sp. nov.
can be distinguished by the smooth embolus axis (
; embolus bearing a membranous lamella on the prolateral side in
S. barbado
sp. nov.
,
). Among the species with known females,
R. otti
sp. nov.
is most similar to
R. ruizi ( Zhang & Maddison, 2015 )
comb. nov.
, given their narrow, inverted V-shaped coupling pocket, but it can be distinguished by the longer loop in the middle portion of the copulatory duct (
; smaller loop in
R. ruizi
, see Zhang & Maddison 2015 : figs 279–280).

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Mata Samuel de Paula , Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural , Nova Lima , Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 20°S , 43.867°W ),
12–18.X.2006
, J.P.P. Pena-Barbosa et al. leg. ( UFMG 2933 )
.
Paratypes :
1♂ 1♀ , female from Estação Ecológica da Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais , Belo Horizinte , Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 19.874°S 43.972°W ),
IX.2000
, unknown coll. (UFMG 8298)
.
Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a Latin adjective, is due to two bands of white stripes present dorsally, extending from the anterior region of the cephalic area to the end of the abdomen.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
is similar to those of
R. crispiventer ( Ruiz, 2011 )
comb. nov.
and
R. excentrica ( Ruiz, 2013 )
comb. nov.
by the long embolus coiled clockwise (left palp; in most species with long embolus, the embolus coils anti-clockwise). As in
R. crispiventer
, the base of the embolus is hidden distally under the rounded tegulum (dislocated prolaterally in
R. excentrica
), but the embolus is longer in
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
(
) when comparing to
R. crispiventer
(see Ruiz 2011 : figs 10–12). Those three species share a cluster of modified bristles ventrally on the posterior region of the abdomen (
,
).
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
is also easily distinguished from other species by having a pair of bands of white scale on the dorsum of the carapace and abdomen (in both male and female). The female differs from those of other species by having a complete loop in the initial portion of copulatory duct (
).

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Minas Gerais , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Fazenda São Nicolau , Cotriguaçu , Mato Grosso , Brazil ( 9.840°S , 58.248°W ),
2–14.X.2010
, A.J. Santos leg. (UFMG 7696).
Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a Latin adjective, refers to the type locality.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. cotriguacuensis
sp. nov .
is similar to those
R. tocantinensis
sp. nov.
and
R. ruizi
by having a short and wide embolus, projecting from the prolateral region of the tegulum and covered by a membranous layer (
), but differs by the more cylindrical shape of the embolus with a small apophysis at the apical region, as well as a simple and curved RTA directed towards the posterior region of the bulb (
).
Female. Unknown.

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Mato Grosso , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural Canguçu , Centro de Pesquisa Canguçu , Pium , Tocantins , Brazil ( 9.977°S 50.085°W ),
18.V.2016
, leg. A.B. Bonaldo et al. (MPEG 39057).
Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a Latin adjective, was built based on the type locality.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. tocantinensis
sp. nov.
is similar to those of
R. cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
and
R. ruizi (Zhang & Maddison, 2012)
comb. nov.
by having a short and wide embolus, projecting from the prolateral region of the tegulum and partially covered by a membranous layer (
), but differs from them by having an apical constriction in the embolus, and by a robust RTA directed toward the center of the tegulum (
).
Female. Unknown.

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Tocantins , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Campus Embrapa , Rio Branco , Acre , Brazil ( 10.025°S , 67.693°W ),
VIII.2012
, L.M.S. Costa leg. (UFMG 12402).
Etymology. Epithet, a Latin noun in apposition, is due to the shape of the RTA, reminiscent of a chicken wing.

Diagnosis. The male is similar to that of
R. amrishi
by having a smooth embolus projecting from a sclerotized distal region and reaching the tip of the cymbium (
). However, it differs by having an elongate RTA curved towards the center of the tegulum (
; short in
R. amrishi
, see Ruiz & Sobrinho (2016 : fig. 6).
Female. Unknown.

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Acre , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Estação Ecológica de Jureia-Itatins (Núcleo Arpoador), Peruíbe , São Paulo , Brazil ( 24.387°S , 47.017°W ),
21–26.IV.2012
, G.H.F. Azevedo & J.P.P. Pena-Barbosa leg. (UFMG 13046).
Etymology. Epithet, a noun in apposition, is due to the shape of the embolus tip, reminiscent of a typical planarian head.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. planaria
sp. nov.
is similar to those
R. otti
sp. nov.
and
R. barbado
sp. nov.
for having a thin embolus with an apical twist (
), but differs for being shorter.
Female. Unknown.

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( São Paulo , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Mata Samuel de Paula , Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural , Nova Lima , Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 20°S , 43.867°W ),
12–18.X.2006
, J.P.P. Pena-Barbosa et al. leg. (UFMG 2949)
.
Paratype :
1♀ , same data as holotype (UFMG 2950)
.
Etymology. The epithet, a noun in apposition, was taken from the type locality.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. novalima
sp. nov.
is similar to those of
R. tabernarius ( Ruiz, 2013 )
comb nov.
and
S. minima ( Ruiz, 2011 )
comb. nov.
by the spiraled embolus, but it differs from both by having a less compact spiral (
). The female differs from all other known species by having the copulatory openings facing ectally, towards the laterals of the abdomen, with the copulatory ducts running posteriorly (
).

Note. As stated, typical species of
Rhyphelia
do not have the typical spiraled embolus of Euophryini. However, the embolus of
R. novalima
sp. nov.
is reminiscent of the typical euophryine embolus. This feature is interpretated here as a reversion, since size, coloration and epigyne conformation are typical for the genus.

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Minas Gerais , Brazil ) (
).

mixed-citation.named-content: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Pico do Sol , Santuário do Caraça , Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural , Santa Barbara , Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 20.059°S , 43.505°W ),
7.X.2010
, L.N Perillo leg. (UFMG 6606).
Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a noun in apposition, is due to the embolus and paraembolic apophysis reminiscent of the sign for “okay ” in LIBRAS, the Brazilian Sign Language.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. okay
sp. nov.
differs from all other known species of
Rhyphelia
by having an apophysis projecting from the base of the embolus towards the apex of the cymbium (
). The female is similar to those of
R. otti
sp. nov.
and
R. ruizi
for the narrow coupling pocket on the epigyne (
), but differs by the shorter copulatory ducts (loops close to spermathecae).

Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Minas Gerais , Brazil ) (
).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The genus
Rhyphelia
presents a great variation regarding palpal morphology, with at least three possible positions for the embolus base. The species
R. amrishi , R. albipes , R. chaplini , R. cymbialis , R. dromedarius , R. lunata , R. macrochelis , R. tabernarius , R. spinipes
,
R. variegata
and
R. brevistylus
have the embolus base distally on the bulb, while
R. bicrescens
,
R. cearensis , R. aurifrons , R. laticlavus , R. muiratinga , R. paxiuba , R. ruizi
, and
R. trombetas
have the embolus base in a more median region of the bulb, which is a possible intermediate among the three variations. The species
R. elongatula , R. flagelator
, and
R. micacea
have the embolus base in the most proximal region of the bulb, with a spiraled and elongate embolus. The varying embolus length (and base position), however, may represent only grades and no species group is based on that character so far. Once more species are described, and possibly unknown females of others, a more complete scenario can be established based on phylogenetic studies.

Despite these limitations in delimiting species groups based on embolus morphology, a group composed of three species can be formed based on well-evident morphological characters that distinguish them from the other described species.
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
,
R. crispiventer
and
R. excentrica
have a long embolus that is coiled clockwise (left palp), unusual for the genus. In most other species with long embolus, the embolus coils anti-clockwise in the left palp, as in most Euophryini. Also, these three species seem to have a hooked apophysis near the embolus base (see Figs 10A , 11D ), and they share a cluster of modified bristles ventrally on the posterior region of the abdomen ( Figs 8B , 12 ). These setae are believed to have a stridulatory function during courtship and are well developed in males only.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: We would like to thank Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior (CAPES) (WBN) and Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (CNPq, PQ# 312604/2022-0; GRSR) for the support. We would also like to thank the Universidade Federal do Pará (UFPA), the Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi (MPEG) and their Graduate Program in Zoology (PPGZOOL) for the facilities. To Adalberto Santos (UFMG), Élise-Anne Leguin and Christine Rollard (MNHN), and Ricardo Ott (MCN) for sending specimens. To Histon Costi and Laura Miglio for helping with SEM illustrations. Also, to Abel Bustamante for the constant support to WBN during the development of this work. Finally, to the members of the evaluation board (Dr Abel Antonio Bustamante Ferrada, Dr Antonio Domingos Brescovit, Dr Fernando Augusto Barbosa Silva and Dra Regiane Saturnino Ferreira) for the comments on the academic version of this paper presented to the Programa de Pós-Graduação em Zoologia of the Universidade Federal do Pará / Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi.
